# Summary of EIA Gasoline Price Data

## Key Information

**Source:** U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)  
**Data Type:** U.S. Regular All Formulations Retail Gasoline Prices (Dollars per Gallon)  
**Release Date:** 2/3/2026  
**Next Release Date:** 2/10/2026

## Relevant Data Points

The article presents a table of annual average gasoline prices by decade. Most relevant to the forecasting question:

**2020s decade prices (annual averages):**
- 2020: $2.168/gallon
- 2021: $3.008/gallon
- 2022: $3.951/gallon
- 2023: $3.519/gallon
- 2024: $3.304/gallon
- 2025: $3.097/gallon

## Important Notes

- This data shows **annual averages**, not monthly values
- The question asks specifically for **March 2026** monthly data, which is not yet available in this table
- The table shows a general declining trend in annual average prices from 2022 ($3.951) through 2025 ($3.097)
- The resolution source URL provided in the question (https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=emm_epmr_pte_nus_dpg&f=a) would contain monthly data when available

**Disclaimer:** This article contains only historical annual average data and does not include the March 2026 monthly figure needed to resolve the forecasting question.
</QuestionSource>


<Summary source="https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/GASREGCOVW">
## Summary of Article

**Source:** FRED (Federal Reserve Economic Data), St. Louis Fed - US Regular Conventional Gas Price data series

**Key Information:**

### Data Source and Methodology:
- **Primary Source:** U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)
- **Release Name:** Gasoline and Diesel Fuel Update
- **Sampling Method:** Weighted average based on approximately 900 retail outlets
- **Collection Time:** 8:00 AM Monday (weekly frequency)
- **Price Type:** Self-service prices (or full-service if self-service unavailable)
- **Inclusions:** All taxes included; covers both conventional gasoline and reformulated gasoline under "All Formulations"

### Technical Details:
- **Units:** Dollars per Gallon
- **Seasonal Adjustment:** Not Seasonally Adjusted
- **Frequency:** Weekly
- **Series Code:** GASREGCOVW

### Notes:
This article is primarily a metadata description of the FRED data series for US Regular Conventional Gas Price. It does not contain actual price data, forecasts, expert opinions, or statistics about current or future gasoline prices. The content describes how the data is collected and reported but does not provide substantive information that would directly inform a forecast for March 2026 gasoline prices.

**Disclaimer:** This appears to be a data series description page rather than an analytical article with forecasting-relevant content. No actual price data, trends, or expert analysis is provided in the extracted content.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=emm_epmr_pte_nus_dpg&f=a">
# Summary of EIA Gasoline Price Data

## Key Data Points:

**Historical Annual Average Prices (Dollars per Gallon):**

The article presents a table of U.S. Regular All Formulations Retail Gasoline Prices showing annual averages by decade:

- **1990s range:** $1.03 - $1.20 per gallon
- **2000s range:** $1.35 - $3.25 per gallon (with peak in 2008 at $3.246)
- **2010s range:** $2.14 - $3.62 per gallon (with peak in 2012 at $3.618)
- **2020s (available data):**
  - 2020: $2.168
  - 2021: $3.008
  - 2022: $3.951
  - 2023: $3.519
  - 2024: $3.304
  - 2025: $3.097

## Important Notes:

- **Data Release Date:** 2/3/2026
- **Next Release Date:** 2/10/2026
- The data shows annual averages, not monthly values
- No March 2026 monthly data is present in this table (the table only contains annual averages)

**Disclaimer:** This article contains only annual average gasoline prices and does not include the specific monthly data for March 2026 that would directly resolve the forecasting question. The forecaster will need to wait for the monthly data to be published at the specified EIA link.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=ema_epmru_pta_nus_dpg&f=a">
## Summary of Article

**Source:** U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)

**Content Type:** Historical data table

**Key Information:**

This article presents a historical data table showing U.S. Conventional Gasoline Regular Retail Sales prices by all sellers, measured in dollars per gallon.

**Historical Price Data (Annual Averages):**

- **1990s:** Prices ranged from $0.610 (1994) to $0.801 (1992)
- **2000s:** Prices showed an upward trend, ranging from $0.901 (2002) to $2.731 (2008), with a drop to $1.842 in 2009
- **2010s:** Only 2010 data is shown at $2.267 per gallon
- **2020s:** No data reported

**Data Notes:**
- Release Date: 6/1/2022
- Next Release Date: TBD (To Be Determined)
- The table uses conventional gasoline data, which may differ from the "All Formulations" data specified in the forecasting question's resolution criteria

**Disclaimer:** This data table only provides historical annual averages through 2010 and does not contain recent data, forecasts, or monthly breakdowns. The data is also specifically for "Conventional Gasoline" rather than "All Formulations" gasoline that the forecasting question references, so there may be methodological differences in measurement.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.rigzone.com/news/gasbuddy_reveals_2026_usa_gasoline_price_forecast-14-jan-2026-182765-article/">
# Summary of GasBuddy 2026 USA Gasoline Price Forecast

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**Annual Forecasts:**
- **2026 annual average U.S. gasoline price**: $2.97 per gallon (fourth consecutive annual decline, lowest since 2020)
- **2025 annual average**: $3.102 per gallon
- **Average household spending on gasoline in 2026**: $2,083 (lowest since 2021's $1,979)

**Monthly Forecasts for 2026:**
- **Highest month**: May at $3.12 per gallon
- **Lowest month**: December at $2.83 per gallon
- **December projection**: Near $2.80 per gallon (mentioned separately in the article)

**Current Price Data (as of January 14, 2026):**
- GasBuddy live average: $2.844 per gallon
- AAA average: $2.840 per gallon

## Named Source Opinions:

**Patrick De Haan, Head of Petroleum Analysis at GasBuddy:**
- Attributes the decline to "unwinding of post-pandemic market distortions, expanding global refining capacity, and more stable supply chains"
- Expects "traditional seasonal pattern" in 2026 with spring peak in "low $3.20 range" driven by summer gasoline switch and refinery maintenance
- Notes 2026 spring peak forecast to be lower than 2025, "signaling a softening market"
- Projects prices to decline steadily after June
- States "If the market avoids major surprises, sustained averages below $3 per gallon could become commonplace in the year ahead"
- Characterized 2025 as "a year of rare stability"

## Relevant Context:
The forecast does not provide a specific projection for **March 2026**, which is the month in question. The article only specifies May (highest at $3.12) and December (lowest at $2.83) as specific monthly forecasts.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://wjon.com/gas-prices-2026-forecast/">
## Summary of Article: "2026 Forecasts Suggest Gas Prices Will Average $2.97 A Gallon"

**Source:** AM 1240 WJON

### Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **2026 Annual Average Forecast:** $2.97 per gallon for regular gasoline nationally
   - This represents a 13-cent decrease from the 2025 average of $3.10 per gallon
   - Would be the first time below $3 per gallon since the COVID-19 pandemic
   - Would mark the fourth consecutive year of declining gas prices

2. **Seasonal Price Variations Expected in 2026:**
   - Spring: Prices may briefly reach the $3.20s during the switch to summer gasoline
   - Post-June: Prices are likely to fall
   - December 2026 forecast: $2.83 per gallon average

3. **Diesel Forecast:**
   - 2026 national average: $3.55 per gallon
   - Down from $3.62 in 2025

4. **Consumer Spending Projections:**
   - Motorists projected to spend $11 billion less on gasoline in 2026 compared to 2025
   - Average household projected to spend approximately $2,083 on gas in 2026 (down slightly from 2025)

### Source Attribution:
- The forecasts are attributed to "Gas Buddy" (mentioned once in the article regarding spring price peaks)
- The article does not specify the original source or methodology for all forecasts presented
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://abc6onyourside.com/news/nation-world/gasbuddy-forecasts-2026-gas-prices-below-3-per-gallon-for-first-time-since-pandemic-gasoline-economy-affordability-energy">
# Summary of GasBuddy 2026 Fuel Price Outlook

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **2026 National Average Projection**: $2.97 per gallon for the year
   - This represents a 13-cent decrease from 2025's average of $3.10
   - Would be the lowest yearly average since 2020
   - First time below $3 per gallon since the COVID-19 pandemic

2. **Seasonal Price Forecasts**:
   - Spring peak: prices reaching the low $3.20s
   - Decline expected after June
   - December 2026: forecasted average of $2.83

3. **Regional Variations**:
   - Gulf Coast and South: expected to maintain prices well under $3
   - California, Northeast, and Chicago: will remain high-cost areas (though below 2022 highs)

4. **Diesel Prices**: Expected to average $3.55 per gallon for the year (remaining high compared to gasoline but easing from recent peaks)

5. **Consumer Savings**: 
   - Motorists projected to spend $11 billion less on gasoline in 2026 compared to 2025
   - Average household spending estimated at $2,083 (slight decrease from previous year)

## Named Source Opinion:

**Patrick De Haan, Head of Petroleum Analysis at GasBuddy**: Attributes the price decline to global economic recovery from pandemic disruptions and Russia's Ukraine invasion, noting that global central banks' economic cooling measures and new refining capacity have contributed to easing fuel prices since 2022. He suggests that if major market surprises are avoided, sustained averages below $3 per gallon could become commonplace in 2026.

## Volatility Factors Mentioned:
- Seasonal demand
- Refinery maintenance
- Hurricane season
- Geopolitical risks
</Summary>

<Agent_report>
Query: Provide historical monthly U.S. Regular All Formulations Retail Gasoline Prices series, current RBOB gasoline futures curve through April 2026, and key points from the February 2026 EIA STEO gasoline price outlook.
Below is what can be assembled from the material returned so far, followed by the information that is still missing and what additional searches would be required.

1. Historical monthly U.S. Regular All Formulations Retail Gasoline Prices  
   •  The FRED series GASREGM (“US Regular All Formulations Gas Price, Dollars / Gallon, monthly end-of-period”) provides the complete history back to September 1990.  
      – Latest value (Jan-2026): $2.81 / gal, down 8.7 % year-on-year (FRED series GASREGM).  
      – Selected recent values (end-of-period):  
        • Apr-2025 $3.17  • Jul-2025 $3.12  • Oct-2025 $3.06  • Dec-2025 $2.89  • Jan-2026 $2.81 (FRED GASREGM).  
      – Long-run statistics: all-time mean $2.26 / gal; historical minimum $0.92 / gal (Feb-1999); maximum $4.93 / gal (Jun-2022) (FRED GASREGM).  
   •  These data satisfy the “historical monthly price series” part of the query.

2. Current RBOB gasoline futures curve through April 2026  
   •  We have one point on the curve – the April 2026 NYMEX contract trading at $2.2024 / gal as of 1:41 a.m. EST (CNBC quote for @RB.2, expiring 31-Mar-2026).  
   •  However, no prices were returned for the intervening delivery months (Mar-2026, Feb-2026, …, prompt months in 2025-2024).  The CME Group landing page that was captured only describes contract specs and does not list the strip (CME Group RBOB page).  Consequently the complete curve cannot yet be plotted or tabulated from the material at hand.

3. Key points from the February 2026 EIA Short-Term Energy Outlook (STEO) gasoline price outlook  
   •  The EIA has not yet released the February 2026 STEO – the agency website states “Next release date  February 10 2026” (EIA STEO petroleum products page, release dated 13-Jan-2026).  
   •  The most recent outlook available is the January 2026 STEO (released 13-Jan-2026).  Key gasoline take-aways from that report:  
      – EIA projects average U.S. retail regular gasoline price at $2.92 / gal for 2026, down 6 % (-$0.18) from 2025’s $3.10 / gal average (EIA STEO Jan-2026).  
      – Prices edge up to $2.95 / gal in 2027 as crude prices firm slightly and West Coast refinery capacity tightens (EIA STEO Jan-2026).  
      – 2026 decline driven mainly by lower crude oil prices, partially offset by a rebound in refining margins as domestic inventories tighten and West Coast capacity falls (EIA STEO Jan-2026).  
      – EIA expects gasoline prices to fall in every PADD in 2026, then rise again in all regions in 2027, with the West Coast showing the largest 2027 increase (EIA STEO Jan-2026).  
   •  Because the February 2026 edition is not yet posted, none of its “key points” can be summarized at this time.

Remaining information gaps
A. Full RBOB futures strip (all monthly contracts from the prompt month through April 2026).  
B. February 2026 STEO gasoline outlook (the report releases later today).  Access to the PDF or data browser after publication will be required.

Recommended follow-up searches (different from those already executed)
1. rbob futures settlement prices curve (Google) – should pull up CME or ICE pages that list daily settlements for each contract month.  
2. site:eia.gov february 2026 steo gasoline (Google) – once the report is live, this will locate the specific February publication for the gasoline section.

Until the two items above are obtained, the answer is necessarily partial.</Agent_report>
